s: It is a unique gift to you for taking your time to hear my vision of new safety for the worldâ€™s animals and my request for your hard-earned money The simple fact is we cannot continue without your generous gifts.
This case is about duration, but Congress from time to time -- in fact, you mentioned --
This case is about duration, but Congress from time to time -- in fact, you mentioned --
-- the expanded applications of copyright, and Congress itself extends the scope from time to time.
-- the expanded applications of copyright, and Congress itself extends the scope from time to time.
We've said it must be looked to to interpret the scope of "limited times," and unless retrospective extensions are forbidden, it will eviscerate the meaning of "limited times."
We've said it must be looked to to interpret the scope of "limited times," and unless retrospective extensions are forbidden, it will eviscerate the meaning of "limited times."

Justice, the theory, which would advance the aim of limiting times in a way that is enforceable, is only applicable in the case that we brought before you here to the '98 act, and would not necessarily be applicable under the '76 act for the reasons the Government has offered.
Yes, but the Framers seem adopted these two things at the same time --
It contains -- the clause itself contains limitations, limited times, authors, exclusive rights and things of that nature.

It isn't inconsistent, I submit, Justice Stevens, for the Congress to exercise its juris -- its responsibility under this broad grant of power to determine that there could be many ways in which the holder of an existing right may benefit the public by continuing to have that right for an additional period of time, the same reason that Congress -- same reasons that Congress had when it created the right in the first place.
It is -- well, it -- let me say with respond -- in response to both of those questions, an unlimited time would violate the Copyright Clause.
It is -- well, it -- let me say with respond -- in response to both of those questions, an unlimited time would violate the Copyright Clause.

General Olson, you say that the functional equivalent of an unlimited time would be a violation, but that's precisely the argument that's being made by petitioners here, that a limited time which is extendable is the functionable, functional equivalent of an unlimited time, a limited time that 10 years from now can be extended, and then extended again, and extended again.

General Olson, you say that the functional equivalent of an unlimited time would be a violation, but that's precisely the argument that's being made by petitioners here, that a limited time which is extendable is the functionable, functional equivalent of an unlimited time, a limited time that 10 years from now can be extended, and then extended again, and extended again.

General Olson, you say that the functional equivalent of an unlimited time would be a violation, but that's precisely the argument that's being made by petitioners here, that a limited time which is extendable is the functionable, functional equivalent of an unlimited time, a limited time that 10 years from now can be extended, and then extended again, and extended again.

General Olson, you say that the functional equivalent of an unlimited time would be a violation, but that's precisely the argument that's being made by petitioners here, that a limited time which is extendable is the functionable, functional equivalent of an unlimited time, a limited time that 10 years from now can be extended, and then extended again, and extended again.
Why -- their argument is precisely that, a limited time doesn't mean anything unless it means, once you have established the limit for works that have been created under that limit, that's the end.
The petitioners are only saying that there shall be a per se rule that the word "limited times," means unchangeable times.
The petitioners are only saying that there shall be a per se rule that the word "limited times," means unchangeable times.

Is it also your argument that even if you cannot trace that kind, or at least plausibly argue that there could be that kind of a causal benefit, that it would still be constitutional, because you should judge the extension simply as contributing to a general system, one feature of which is that from time to time there may be retrospective extensions, and so long as that general system induces the creation of works, or the dissemination of works, or the preservation of works, so long as the general system works, there is no review, no limitation on the tinkering that can be done, even retrospectively?

Is it also your argument that even if you cannot trace that kind, or at least plausibly argue that there could be that kind of a causal benefit, that it would still be constitutional, because you should judge the extension simply as contributing to a general system, one feature of which is that from time to time there may be retrospective extensions, and so long as that general system induces the creation of works, or the dissemination of works, or the preservation of works, so long as the general system works, there is no review, no limitation on the tinkering that can be done, even retrospectively?

Well, of course, the original statute was replacing a bunch of State statutes or State rules, partly common law, partly statutory, that -- they had kind of a mixed up legal situation, and there was an interest in having one uniform rule for the first time around.
But there will be Mondays on which I am not at home from 7 pm to midnight (that's 12 noon to 5 pm EST, since we're in daylight saving time as of last weekend).
[Jack starts to walk off, but Bootstrap stands up at the same time and intercepts Jack, blocking him]
[the men in Will's cage are unable to the cage open in time before the cannibals will reach them]
WILL TURNER Time to go.
JACK SPARROW Time to go?
[Jack makes his way upstairs, trading hats a few times along the way]
[Bootstrap whips Will's back five times]
DAVY JONES You need time alone with your thoughts.
[a sword is thrown to Elizabeth, just in time]
[a sword is thrown to Pintel, just in time]
[a sword is thrown to Ragetti, just in time]

Following establishment of this initial mail classification schedule, Â§ 3623(b) provides that the Postal Service "may from time to time request that the Commission submit, or the Commission may submit to the Governors on its own initiative, a recommended decision on changes in the mail classification schedule."
